channel.title: Comments on: R. Bernard Lander, Officer Krupke, and Rav Moshe Feinstein
channel.description: notes on Jewish theology and spirituality

item.title: By: Jonathan Hirsch
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Hirsch
item.description: Did Rabbi Lander ever offer a critque of Modern Orthodoxy (based on the ideas mentioned) it is a a shame that people like him did not help shape Modern Orthodoxy ,I know people who chose to live in the Yeshiva world(although they philosphically identify as Modern Orthodox ) since they feel economically intimidated by Modern Orthodoxy emphasis of a suburban lifestyle
item.content:encoded: Did Rabbi Lander ever offer a critque of Modern Orthodoxy (based on the ideas mentioned) it is a a shame that people like him did not help shape Modern Orthodoxy ,I know people who chose to live in the Yeshiva world(although they philosphically identify as Modern Orthodox ) since they feel economically intimidated by Modern Orthodoxy emphasis of a suburban lifestyle

item.title: By: lawrence kaplan
item.dc:creator: lawrence kaplan
item.description:
Some random observations:
It is interesting that Rav Moshe Feinstein, Rav Yaakov Kamenetsky, Rav Schach, and the Steipler all signed a letter condeminng the opening of a branch of Touro for women in Israel.
BTE, speaking of class, the college tuition for Touro is considerably less than that of YU. Still, as I have heard from a very reliable source, Touro for women has not been able to make a dent in the group of modern Orthodox women High School graduates who choose to go on to Stern.
It is also ironic that Touro in Israel runs a Graduate Program for Jewish Studies, while YU has no such program.
item.content:encoded:
Some random observations:

It is interesting that Rav Moshe Feinstein, Rav Yaakov Kamenetsky, Rav Schach, and the Steipler all signed a letter condeminng the opening of a branch of Touro for women in Israel.

BTE, speaking of class, the college tuition for Touro is considerably less than that of YU. Still, as I have heard from a very reliable source, Touro for women has not been able to make a dent in the group of modern Orthodox women High School graduates who choose to go on to Stern.

It is also ironic that Touro in Israel runs a Graduate Program for Jewish Studies, while YU has no such program.
